title: HadCRUT4 begins
annotation: Temperature data are now available from enough monitoring stations to reliably estimate the global average temperature at the Earth's surface.

title: 285 ppm CO<sub>2</sub>
annotation: Carbon dioxide concentrations in the atmosphere: 285 parts per million (ppm).
Strong El Niño event causes brief global peak in temperature and catastrophic drought in India where 12 million perished.
title: El Niño causes droughts

annotation: Eruption of Mount Krakatoa cools the world – enormous volcanic eruptions like this inject ash high into the atmosphere, reflecting solar radiation back to space and causing global cooling.
title: Krakatoa erupts

annotation: Cooling caused by volcanic eruptions continues into the early 20th century.
title: Volcanic cooling

annotation: Opening of Panama Canal changes shipping routes from Atlantic into Pacific
title: Panama Canal opens

annotation: Recovery from volcanic eruptions, a small increase in solar output, gradual increase in greenhouse gases, and natural variability, all contribute to a period of warming.
title: End of volcanic cooling

annotation: Second World War leads to a drop in global coverage of measurements made by ships
title: WWII

annotation: Prolonged El Niño event.
title: El Niño

annotation: Carbon dioxide concentrations: 311 ppm.
title: CO<sub>2</sub> at 311 ppm

annotation: International Geophysical Year – systematic long-term temperature measurements begin in Antarctica.
title: Measurements begin in Antarctica

annotation: Global temperatures are fairly constant for this period. Emissions of aerosols from human activities have a cooling effect that offsets the warming effects of increasing greenhouse gases.
title: Greenhouse effect offset by aerosol pollution

annotation: Mount Agung erupts cooling large parts of the Earth.
title: Mt. Agung erupts

annotation: Carbon dioxide concentrations: 326 ppm.
title: CO<sub>2</sub> at 326 ppm

annotation: The Great Climate Shift - the Pacific Decadal Oscillation shifts into its positive phase. The late 1970s also saw the start of the late 20th century warming.
title: The Great Climate Shift

annotation: Large release of drifting buoys improves ocean coverage in the Southern Hemisphere.
title: Increase in ocean measurements

annotation: Cooling due to the eruption of El Chichón (March-April 1982) partly offset by warming from a strong El Niño event.
title: El Niño and El Chichón erruption

annotation: Strong El Niño event.
title: El Niño

annotation: Carbon dioxide concentrations: 354 ppm.
title: CO<sub>2</sub> at 543 ppm

annotation: The eruption of Mount Pinatubo creates an ash cloud that envelops the world, cooling large parts of the Earth for several years.
title: Mount Pinatubo erupts

annotation: Exceptionally strong El Niño event causes brief global peak in temperature to record levels.
title: El Niño

annotation: Prolonged La Niña event
title: La Niña

annotation: Carbon dioxide concentrations: 370 ppm.
title: CO<sub>2</sub> at 370 ppm

annotation: The rate of surface warming slows in the early years of the 21st century, despite the continued rise in greenhouse gases. Natural variability in the climate system, augmented by interaction with man-made aerosols, is thought to be responsible along with a contribution from volcanic eruptions.
title: Surface warming slows

annotation: La Niña conditions in 2008, 2011 and 2012 cause temporary drops in global temperatures.
title: La Niña

annotation: Carbon dioxide concentrations: 389 ppm.
title: CO<sub>2</sub> at 389 ppm

annotation: 2014 equals previous global temperature record and 2015 breaks it by a clear margin. 2016 is likely to be even warmer.
title: Series of record warm years

annotation: Strong El Niño event causes rise in global temperature.
title: El Niño

annotation: El Niño augments human-driven warming to give record-breaking warmth. Global temperatures surpass 1 °C above the pre-industrial for the first time.
title: 2015 Record breaking warm year

annotation: Carbon dioxide concentrations now above 400 ppm all year round.
title: CO<sub>2</sub> concentrations break 400 ppm

annotation: Monthly temperatures stay at near-record or record levels from mid-2015 to mid-2016 with the period from November 2015 to April 2016 being particularly warm.
title: Continuing record warmth
